channel.title: math.KT updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.KT updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: The Cylinder Simplicial DG Ring
item.description: arXiv:2602.11943v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Given a DG ring $B$ and an integer $q \geq 0$, we construct the $q$-th cylinder DG ring $Cyl_q(B)$. For $q = 1$ this is just Keller's cylinder DG ring, sometimes called the path object of $B$, which encodes homotopies between DG ring homomorphisms $A \to B$. As $q$ changes the cylinder DG rings form a simplicial DG ring $Cyl(B)$. Hence, given another DG ring $A$, the DG ring homomorphisms $A \to Cyl(B)$ form a simplicial set $Hom(A,Cyl(B))$. Our main theorem states that when $A$ is a semi-free DG ring, the simplicial set $Hom(A,Cyl(B))$ is a Kan complex. For the verification of the Kan condition we introduce a new construction, which may be of independent interest. Given a horn $Y$, we define the DG ring $N(Y,B)$, and we prove that $N(Y,B)$ represents this horn in the simplicial set $Hom(A,Cyl(B))$. In this way the Kan condition is implemented intrinsically in the category of DG rings, thus facilitating calculations. Presumably all the above can be extended, with little change, from DG rings to (small) DG categories. That would enable easy constructions and explicit calculations of some simplicial aspects of DG categories.
item.dc:creator: Amnon Yekutieli

item.title: Algebraic K-theory of finite algebras over higher local fields
item.description: arXiv:2503.20383v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: It is known that the truncated Brown--Peterson spectra can be equipped with a certain nice algebra structure, by the work of J. Hahn and D. Wilson, and these ring spectra can be viewed as rings of integers of local fields in chromatic homotopy theory. Furthermore, they satisfy both Rognes' redshift conjecture and the Lichtenbaum--Quillen property. For lower-height cases, the K-theory of the truncated polynomial algebras over these ring spectra is well understood through the work of L. Hesselholt, I. Madsen, and others. In this paper, we demonstrate that the Segal conjecture fails for truncated polynomial algebras over higher chromatic local fields, and consequently, the Lichtenbaum--Quillen property fails. However, the weak redshift conjecture remains valid. Additionally, we provide some other examples where Segal conjecture holds.
item.dc:creator: Rixin Fang
